data.reasoning: The provided data is extremely limited, consisting only of restaurant contact information and boilerplate navigation links, not an actual menu or customer reviews mentioning allergens. Traditional Thai cuisine inherently carries high cross-contact risk due to the common use of wheat-containing soy sauce, wheat noodles, and shared fryers/woks. The lack of any safety indicators or menu context forces a highly conservative assessment based on cuisine type alone. Confidence is low due to insufficient data.
risk_factors: Absence of explicit menu information prevents identification of gluten-containing ingredients (e.g., soy sauce, wheat noodles, thickeners).
High inherent risk of cross-contact in Thai kitchens (shared woks, fryers, cutting boards).
No confirmation of dedicated gluten-free protocols or staff training mentioned in the limited data.
Celiac customers must assume standard preparation uses wheat-containing soy sauce unless explicitly verified.
safe_alternatives: Cannot confidently identify safe alternatives without a menu or specific GF policy confirmation. Dishes like plain steamed rice might be safe, but sauce preparation is unknown.
